(40)Conclusions of Meeting 119 C.(Meeting of Ministers.)TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of Ministers held in the Admiralty, S.W. 1, on sunday, May 12, 1940, at 10-30 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. Neville Chamberlain,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. A. V. Alexander,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.The Right Hon. Viscount Halifax,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for War.The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.Air Chief Marshal Sir Cyril LNewall, Chief of the Air Staff.The following were also presentN.Admiral of the Fleet Sir dudley pound, First Sea Lord and Chief ofNaval Staff.General Sir W. Edmund Ironside,Chief of the Imperial General Staff.Secretariat.Sir Edward Bridges.Major-General H. L. Ismay.Colonel L. C. Hollis, R.M.j21279cjb MEETING OF MINISTERS119 C(40).Contents.minute no. Subject. page 1 The Western Front .................. 105Progress of operations.Oil supplies in Holland.Royal Marine operation.2 Operations in Norway ... ... ... ... ... ... 105Bodo-Mo area.Narvik.3 Invasion of Great Britain ... ...... ... ... 106Possible air landings on open spaces.4 Air Policy ..................... 106 The western front.Progress of operations.Oil supplies in holland.(previous reference erence:W.M. (40), Con-elusions 119 B,Minute 1.)Eoyal marine operation.1. Ministers were given the latest information in regard tothe operations in Holland and Belgium.The Chief of the Air Staff said that in two days' fighting wehad lost 76 aircraft and had had 40 damaged. As against this, theGerman losses were believed to be in the neighbourhood of 300,of which perhaps 180 were J.U. 88's. He was satisfied as to theresults of the air fighting, except that he thought we were havingundue losses of medium bombers in relation to the results attained.He had sent instructions to the Air Officer Commanding-in-chief in France, to the effect that he must reduce the effort of his medium bombers.In regard to land operations, it was explained that the german advance had slowed down considerably, and that the French andBritish forces had a very good prospect of establishing themselves on the Antwerp-Namur line.The position in Holland, was, however, somewhat more difficult.Ministers were informed that the Chiefs of Staff had given ordersthat the composite Guards Battalion should proceed to the Hookof Holland.The question of sending British and French forces to help the Dutch was considered.It was agreed (i) 3rd French Light Division.To request the Chief of the Imperial General Staff toascertain from the French High Command, and to report tothe War Cabinet whether the Third French Light Division,now at Brest, could be sent to assist the Dutch in the areaof The Hague, and if so how soon, on the understandingthat no special air support to this Division by fighters orA.A. guns could be provided from this country.(ii) 15th Infantry Brigade.That the 15th Infantry Brigade should be made ready for further service overseas, if and where necessary, assoon as possible after completion of leave and refitting,and that the date when they would be ready for despatchshould be notified to the War Cabinet.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs read the latesttelegrams from The Hague on this matter. It seemed that theDutch were fully alive to the importance of this question, and thatthe arrangements being made for demolitions were not unsatis-factory.No information had yet been received as to the effect of fluvialmines.It was agreed To request the Chief of the Air Staff to arrange for an air reconnaissance of the Rhine, as soon as possible, tofind out what results the Royal Marine Operation had sofar achieved, the timing of the reconnaissance to beconcerted with the Naval Staff.Operations in norway.Bodo-Mo area.(previous reference erence:W.M. (40), Con-clusions 119 B,Minute 2.)2. The Prime Minister read a letter which had been receivedfrom the Norwegian Foreign Minister in regard to the withdrawalof Colonel Gubbins and his force from the Mosjoen district to Bodo.It was clear that the Norwegian authorities were greatly perturbedin regard to the withdrawal of our forces from Mosjoen.The Prime Minister commented on the rapid German progressin this area, and expressed the view that the position revealed was far from satisfactory. It was agreed : To request the Chiefs of Staff to consider, as a matterof urgency, a letter, dated the 12th May, from theNorwegian Foreign Minister to the Prime Minister on thesubject of operations in Norway south of Narvik, and theposition in regard to those operations.Narvik. Ministers were given the latest information as to the progressof operations around Narvik which were proceeding satisfactorily.Invasion of 3. Reference was made to the report of the German successGreat Britain. in landing aeroplanes on open spaces such as car-parks and footballPossible air grounds in Holland, and to the need for taking precautions againstlandings on open spaces in this country being used by the enemy in the sameopen spaces way.It was agreed To request the Secretary of State for War, in consultationwith the Secretary of State for Air and the Minister ofHome Security, to arrange for a reconnaissance of all open spaces in the United Kingdom, e.g., football grounds, whichmight be used as landing grounds by enemy troop-carryingaircraft; to take the necessary steps to ensure that theyare rendered unusable for this purpose and to inform theWar Cabinet of the action taken.Air Policy.Employment ofthe heavy bomber force.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 119thConclusions,Minute 1.)4. The question of the employment of our heavy bombers wasconsidered in the light of advice tendered by the Chiefs of Staff,the record of the discussion being contained in the Secretary'standard File.It was agreed (i) That this question should again be considered at a meetingof the War Cabinet to be held at 6 - 30 p.m. on 13th May.(ii) To request the Chief of the Air Staff to explain on Monday,the 13th May, to the Lord Privy Seal and, if possible, tothe Minister without Portfolio, in advance of theMeeting of the War Cabinet, the main considerations involved in the question of the employment of our heavy bomber force.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1.May 12, 1940.
